t: Ecclesiastes 2
The Vanity of Pleasure
I*p said in my heart, “Come now, I will test you with mirth; therefore enjoy pleasure”; but surely, this also was*i vanity.
I said of laughter—“Madness!”; and of mirth, “What does it accomplish?”

I searched in my heart how*i to gratify my flesh with wine, while guiding my heart with wisdom, and how to lay hold on folly, till I might see what was*i good for the sons of men to do under heaven all the days of their lives.
I*p made my works great, I built myself houses, and planted myself vineyards.
I made myself gardens and orchards, and I planted all kinds*i of fruit trees in them.
I made myself water pools from which to water the growing trees of the grove.
I acquired male and female servants, and had servants born in my house. Yes, I had greater possessions of herds and flocks than all who were in Jerusalem before me.

I also gathered for myself silver and gold and the special treasures of kings and of the provinces. I acquired male and female singers, the delights of the sons of men, and*i musical instruments of all kinds.
So*p I became great and excelled more than all who were before me in Jerusalem. Also my wisdom remained with me.
Whatever*pn my eyes desired I did not keep from them. I*ld did not withhold my heart from any pleasure, For*ld my heart rejoiced in all my labor; And*ld this was my reward from all my labor.
Then*ld I looked on all the works that my hands had done And*ld on the labor in which I had toiled; And*ld indeed all was*i vanity and grasping for the wind. There*ild was*i no profit under the sun.
The End of the Wise and the Fool
Then*pn I turned myself to consider wisdom and madness and folly; For*ld what can*i the man do*i who succeeds the king?— Only*ild what he has already done.
Then*ld I saw that wisdom excels folly As*ld light excels darkness.
The*ld wise man’s eyes are*i in his head, But*ld the fool walks in darkness. Yet*ld I myself perceived That*ld the same event happens to them all.
So*ln I said in my heart, “As*ld it happens to the fool, It*ld also happens to me, And*ld why was I then more wise?” Then*ld I said in my heart, “This*ld also is*i vanity.”
For*ld there*i is*i no more remembrance of the wise than of the fool forever, Since*ld all that now is*i will be forgotten in the days to come. And*ld how does a wise man*i die? As*ld the fool!
Therefore*p I hated life because the work that was done under the sun was*i distressing to me, for all is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
Then*p I hated all my labor in which I had toiled under the sun, because I must leave it to the man who will come after me.
And who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will rule over all my labor in which I toiled and in which I have shown myself wise under the sun. This also is*i vanity.
Therefore I turned my heart and despaired of all the labor in which I had toiled under the sun.
For there is a man whose labor is*i with wisdom, knowledge, and skill; yet he must leave his heritage to a man who has not labored for it. This also is*i vanity and a great evil.
For what has man for all his labor, and for the striving of his heart with which he has toiled under the sun?
For all his days are*i sorrowful, and his work burdensome; even in the night his heart takes no rest. This also is vanity.
Nothing*p is*i better for a man than*i that he should eat and drink, and that*i his soul should enjoy good in his labor. This also, I saw, was from the hand of God.
For who can eat, or who can have enjoyment, more than I?

For God*i gives wisdom and knowledge and joy to a man who is*i good in His sight; but to the sinner He gives the work of gathering and collecting, that he may give to him*i who*i is*i good before God. This also is*i vanity and grasping for the wind.
